Anthracnose.Cause: Fungal disease caused by species of Colletotrichum (e.g., C. orbiculare) in cucurbit crops; thrives under warm, humid or rainy conditions, may be seed-borne or soil/plant debris borne.
Anthracnose.Symptoms: Small yellow or water-soaked spots on leaves that enlarge and turn dark brown with possible concentric rings; fruit and stems may also show sunken dark lesions causing rot.
Precautions: Use certified disease-free seed or transplants.
Rotate crops with non-hosts for 2-3 seasons; remove infected debris.
Avoid overhead irrigation and reduce leaf wetness by increasing air circulation.

Chemical: Apply fungicides (e.g., mancozeb or carbendazim) at early onset of lesions and repeat under favourable conditions.
Ensure coverage of leaves, stems and fruit where appropriate.
Organic: Use bio-fungicides or plant-derived extracts (e.g., neem or Trichoderma-based) as preventive sprays.
Maintain soil health and avoid crop stress to reduce susceptibility.

Downy_Mildew.Cause: Oomycete/fungal-type pathogen such as Pseudoperonospora cubensis affecting cucurbits; favoured by high humidity, leaf wetness and moderate temperatures.
Downy_Mildew.Symptoms: On upper surfaces: pale green or yellow spots that turn brown; on undersides: gray to purple fuzzy or downy growth of sporangia; leaves may curl upward, wilt and die, leading to defoliation.
Precautions: Ensure good canopy ventilation and avoid prolonged leaf wetness (especially overnight irrigation).
Monitor forecasts of spore movement and apply protectant sprays pre-emptively when conditions are favourable.
Remove older infected leaves, avoid planting near sources of inoculum.

Chemical: Use protectant fungicides early (before symptoms) under high-risk conditions; alternate modes of action to prevent resistance.
Repeat sprays at intervals according to disease pressure and weather.
Organic: Use biocontrol agents or potassium-based compounds as preventive measures.
Maintain healthy plants via fertilisation and irrigation so they recover better from infection.

Healthy.Cause: No pathogenic infection or physiological disease detected; crop growing under optimal conditions.
Healthy.Symptoms: Uniform green leaves, no lesions, proper vine and fruit development, no distortion or necrosis.
Precautions: Maintain balanced watering and fertilisation regime.
Inspect regularly for early signs of pests, diseases or nutrient deficiencies.
Keep tools and surroundings clean to prevent introduction of pathogens.

Chemical: No treatment required; focus on preventive programmes under high-risk seasons.
Organic: Use compost or vermicompost to enrich soil, apply neem oil or plant-extract sprays periodically as preventive protection.
Ensure plant vigour by avoiding stress (heat, drought, nutrient imbalance).

Mosaic_Virus.Cause: Viral disease such as Watermelon mosaic virus (WMV) or other potyviruses/viruses that infect melons; spread by aphids or other insect vectors, or via infected seed or mechanically.
Mosaic_Virus.Symptoms: Mosaic or mottled pattern of light and dark green on leaves, leaf distortion, stunted growth, fruit deformity or reduction in yield/quality.
Precautions: Use virus-free seed and resistant varieties where available.
Control aphid and other vector populations early; remove alternate host weeds.
Sanitise equipment and avoid moving from infected to clean fields.

Chemical: No direct chemical cure for the virus itself; focus on controlling vectors and secondary infections.
Organic: Use reflective mulches or barrier crops to reduce aphid landing.
Encourage natural predators of vectors (e.g., parasitic wasps, ladybugs) and maintain plant health via organic amendments.
